page.lettertext:
fol.276r
20 Au
g
To my L. Trea
s
by the Post
Upon
e closing of my former, I receaved her
Highnes
l
re
to
e States
of
e 2 of this moneth, and your L. to my self, of
e selfe same date.
I hope your L. is resolved
at in as muche as I am able, there hath
w
a
ted no endevour; to give good order for
e c
o
panies. They have bin
in garrison more then a moneth, and are still in a readines, to marche
when they are sent for. For I have allwayes bin
suaded, as I have
formerly signified,
at
e States will give no leave, howsoever they shall
be urged, but yet I stande not in doubt of any publicke impeachem
t
.
And therefor whensoever her M
tie
shall send, I will accomplishe for
my self, w
at
is possible for me, and I knowe
S
r
Francis Vere
will be
wanting to nothing. Upon
e delivery of this l
re
of her
M
tie
and my instance unto them, to receave their p
nt
answear,
they have signified unto me,
at they have sent ex
p
ssely to
Count
Maurice
, to
e
Councel of State
, and to
e Deputies of
e Provinces,
at are
at
e campe, to demaunde their advise, w
ch
being understoode, they will
take some finall resolution, and impart it unto me. I have answeared
againe
at for mine owne part I doe expect every houre, to be c
o
manded by
her Hig
nes
to cause
e C
o
panies to be shipped: w
ch
charge coming to me, I might
not attend w
at
they would resolve: and therefor wished them to thinke upo[n]
a speedier course of dealing. Of
e strength of
e C
o
panies
at were in
e
field w
t
S
r
Francis Vere, I thinke your L. by this is
fitly informed. For
M
r
Allen
e Comissary of
e musters hath sent a man of purpose to
deliver his bookes to
S
r
Thomas Wilkes
. I will send to S
r
Francis out of
hand, and signify of all
at your L. hath written. What
hath moved
e States to send for
Mons
r
Caron
, I can not certify assur[edly]
nor he is not yet come hether. But to shewe your L. my c
o
jecture, [that it]
is a good while since
at I have heard,
at they have greatly disliked o[f .]
his following of their busines for
at they thought, as hath bin say[ed]
at he was partially inclined to proceede in their affaires to her Ma
t[ies]
best liking. And therfore whether it be to revoke him cleane, [or]
to instruct him otherwise, or for some other cause, I will learne
if I can, and lett your L. understande it.
And so I take my hum[ble]
leave. From
e Hage. Au
g
20 1592.
